title: Law enforcement in Indonesia
text:
<a href="Law%20enforcement">Law enforcement</a> in <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a> is mainly performed by the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police">Indonesian National Police</a> (POLRI), together with other <a href="law%20enforcement%20agencies">law enforcement agencies</a> which are under the command of a certain <a href="Cabinet%20of%20Indonesia%23Current%20Cabinet">ministry</a> or <a href="State-owned%20enterprise">State-owned company</a> (BUMN) which perform policing duties for a certain <a href="public%20service">public service</a>, these law enforcement agencies are under supervision and are trained by the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police">Indonesian National Police</a>. The Indonesian National Police is basically the <a href="Indonesia">national</a> <a href="civilian%20police">civilian police</a> force of the country responsible for enforcing law and order of the state.
Police forces.
Indonesian National Police.
The <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police">Indonesian National Police</a> (POLRI) is the main agency responsible for maintaining security and public order, law enforcement, and provide protection and service to the <a href="people">community</a> in <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>. The force is a centralised organisation with responsibilities ranging from <a href="Traffic%20police">traffic control</a>, <a href="criminal%20investigation">criminal investigation</a>, intelligence gathering and <a href="Detachment%2088">counter-terrorism</a> duties. The Indonesian National Police is the national policing force of Indonesia with its headquarters located in <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a>. It is under the auspices of the <a href="President%20of%20Indonesia">President of Indonesia</a>.
The highest command of the national police in Indonesia is executed in Jakarta, at the Indonesian National Police Headquarters (Mabes Polri) located at Trunojoyo Street, <a href="Kebayoran%20Baru">Kebayoran Baru</a>, <a href="South%20Jakarta">South Jakarta</a>. The National Police HQ oversees every <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police%23Police%20operational%20regions">provincial police</a> of the country, each <a href="Province%20of%20Indonesia">Province of Indonesia</a> has its own Police Headquarters known as "POLDA" an abbreviation of "Kepolisian Daerah" in <a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>, it oversees several city or regional police departments which are responsible for a <a href="city">city</a> or <a href="Kabupaten">regency ("Kabupaten")</a> in the province, it is known as "POLRES" ("Kepolisian Resort"), a "Polres" then oversees several police stations responsible for a <a href="Kecamatan">sub-district ("kecamatan")</a> known as "POLSEK" ("Kepolisian Sektor").
Special units of the Indonesian National Police.
The Detachment 88 or known locally as "Densus 88" is the special <a href="counter-terrorism">counter-terrorism</a> unit of the Indonesian National Police.
The Mobile Brigade Corps or known locally as "Brimob" is the paramilitary force of the Indonesian National Police tasked to conduct high-risk law enforcement such as <a href="counterinsurgency">counterinsurgency</a>, <a href="riot%20control">riot control</a>, and <a href="hostage%20rescue">hostage rescue</a>. It is the <a href="Police%20tactical%20unit">PTU</a> and <a href="SWAT">SWAT</a> unit of Polri. Their uniform is the same like other police units, but wear a <a href="Dark%20blue%20%28color%29">dark blue</a> beret as their headgear, during <a href="Urban%20area">urban</a>-operational duties, they wear black uniforms and during <a href="Jungle%20warfare">jungle</a>-operational duties, they wear green. Each provincial police headquarters (Polda) in Indonesia has a Brimob unit.
Municipal police.
The <a href="Municipal%20Police%20%28Indonesia%29">Municipal Police Units</a> (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Satuan Polisi Pamong Praja" abbreviated "Satpol PP") are <a href="municipal%20police">municipal police</a> units which are controlled by the local governments in the country (either <a href="Provinces%20of%20Indonesia">province</a>, <a href="List%20of%20regencies%20and%20cities%20of%20Indonesia">regency, or city</a>), it is under the supervision of the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Home%20Affairs%20%28Indonesia%29">Ministry of Home Affairs</a>. Their responsibilities are to enforce <a href="Regional%20regulation%20%28Indonesia%29">local laws</a>, such as taking action against illegal settlements and structures in the <a href="Cities%20of%20Indonesia">city</a>, bring order towards <a href="Hawker%20%28trade%29">street vendors</a> and <a href="buskers">buskers</a>, and to ensure the safety of city property. They are also responsible to secure the office of the <a href="Mayor">City Mayor</a> and provincial <a href="Governor">Governor</a>. Their operational <a href="uniform">uniform</a> color is greenish-dark <a href="Khaki">Khaki</a>, in <a href="Jakarta">Jakarta</a> they sometimes wear <a href="Orange%20%28color%29">orange</a> polo shirts with khaki cargo pants.
Forestry police.
The <a href="Indonesia%20Forest%20Rangers">Indonesia Forest Rangers</a> (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Polisi Kehutanan" abbreviated "Polhut") is under the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Environment%20and%20Forestry%20%28Indonesia%29">Ministry of Environment and Forestry</a>. One of their responsibilities is to take action against <a href="illegal%20logging">illegal logging</a> and patrol <a href="national%20parks">national parks</a> of the country.
Prison police.
The Prison Police (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Polisi Khusus Lembaga Pemasyarakatan" abbreviated "Polsuspas") are <a href="Prison%20officer">Correctional Officers</a> under the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Law%20and%20Human%20Rights%20%28Indonesia%29">Ministry of Law and Human Rights</a>, they control and supervise <a href="prisons">prisons</a> across the country. Their uniform color is blue.
Railroad police.
The <a href="Railroad%20police%23Indonesia">Railroad Police</a> (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Polisi Khusus Kereta Api" abbreviated "Polsuska") is the <a href="railway%20police">railway police</a> unit which is under the auspices of the <a href="Indonesian%20Railway%20Company">Indonesian Railway Company</a>. They are not under a certain <a href="Ministry%20%28government%20department%29">ministry</a>, rather they are part of the Directorate of Safety and Security of the <a href="Indonesian%20Railway%20Company">Indonesian Railway Company</a>, but are trained and educated by the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police">Indonesian National Police</a>. Their uniform is black and wear orange <a href="beret">beret</a>s, they are usually posted in Railway stations.
Remote Islands and Coastal Development police.
The Police for Management of Marine, Coastal Region and Remote Islands ("Polisi Khusus Pengelolaan Wilayah Pesisir dan Pulau-Pulau Kecil" abbreviated "Polsus PWP3K") is a newly specialized-formed policing unit under the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Maritime%20Affairs%20and%20Fisheries%20%28Indonesia%29">Ministry of Maritime Affairs and Fisheries</a>, their authority includes conducting patrols in coastal areas and remote islands and to take action towards complaints regarding activities that damage natural maritime resources.
Agricultural quarantine police.
The <a href="Agency%20of%20Agricultural%20Quarantine%20%28Indonesia%29">Agricultural and Animal Quarantine Police</a> (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Polisi Khusus Badan Karantina Pertanian") is a police unit under the Agency of Agricultural Quarantine which is within the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Agriculture%20%28Indonesia%29">Ministry of Agriculture</a>. They perform duties for looking after <a href="Agriculture%20in%20Indonesia">Agricultural</a> and <a href="Animal">Animal</a> <a href="Quarantine">Quarantine</a> affairs.
Military Police Corps.
In <a href="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, the <a href="Military%20Police%20Corps%20%28Indonesia%29">Military Police Command</a> (<a href="Indonesian%20language">Indonesian</a>: "Pusat Polisi Militer TNI" abbreviated "Puspom TNI") is the only institution which has authority to conduct law enforcement towards active members of the <a href="Indonesian%20Military">Indonesian Military</a>, it is an institution which is directly under the auspices of the Indonesian National Armed Forces Headquarters ("Mabes TNI") which heads the three Military Police corps which are the:
The Military Police does not have authority towards <a href="civilian">civilian</a>s as it is the realm of the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police">Indonesian National Police</a> (Polri), and in the other hand, the <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police">civilian Police</a> does not have authority towards active members of the military, except accompanied by the Military police. If a military member is caught red-handed by the civilian police, then the violator will be sent to the Military Police or the Military police would be contacted.
Maritime law enforcement agencies.
Maritime Security Agency.
The Maritime Security Agency () is a maritime patrol of the <a href="Indonesia">Republic of Indonesia</a>. BAKAMLA is a non-ministerial government institution which reports directly to the <a href="President%20of%20Indonesia">President</a> through the <a href="Coordinating%20Ministry%20for%20Political%2C%20Legal%2C%20and%20Security%20Affairs%20%28Indonesia%29">Coordinating Ministry for Political, Legal, and Security Affairs</a>. BAKAMLA's duty is to conduct security and safety patrols in the territorial waters of Indonesia and the jurisdiction of Indonesia.
Sea and Coast Guard.
The Sea and Coast Guard () is an agency of the <a href="Government%20of%20Indonesia">Government of Indonesia</a> which has the main function to ensure the safety of <a href="shipping">shipping</a> activity inside the Indonesian Maritime Zone. The "KPLP" has the task to formulate and execute policies, standards, norms, guidelines, criteria and procedures, as well as technical guidance, evaluation and reporting concerning maritime patrol and security, which is conducted in coordination with other maritime law enforcement agencies of the country such as BAKAMLA, <a href="Water%20police%23Indonesia">Indonesian National Police Water Unit</a>, and also in certain cases with the <a href="Indonesian%20Navy">Indonesian Navy</a>. KPLP is under the auspices of the Directorate General of Sea Transportation of the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Transportation">Indonesian Ministry of Transportation</a> ("Kementerian Perhubungan").
National Police Water Unit.
The <a href="Indonesian%20National%20Police">Indonesian National Police</a> has a <a href="Water%20police">water</a> unit (Indonesian: "Polisi Perairan" abbreviated "Polair") responsible to conduct law enforcement and enforce security and order of the coast and state waters.
Marine and Fisheries Resources Surveillance.
The Marine and Fisheries Resources Surveillance () is a government agency under the management of the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Maritime%20Affairs%20and%20Fisheries%20%28Indonesia%29">Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries of Indonesia</a>. Formally established on 23 November 2000 according to Presidential Decree No. 165/2000, the PSDKP is the agency responsible for <a href="Fisheries%20management">supervising the marine and fishery resources</a> of the Republic of Indonesia.
Criticism.
There has been many criticism by political observers in Indonesia concerning the presence of multiple maritime law enforcement agencies in Indonesia which tend to overlap authority between one another in the maritime zone of the country. As of 2015, maritime law enforcement in Indonesia is conducted by 12 different agencies from different ministries of the government. The <a href="Indonesian%20Navy">Navy</a> is also authorized to conduct maritime law enforcement in certain cases as it is stated in the <a href="Constitution%20of%20Indonesia">constitution</a> of the country.
There has been plans to amalgamate these different maritime law enforcement agencies to become a singular national "Indonesian Coast Guard" such as the <a href="US%20Coast%20Guard">Coast Guard of the United States of America</a> and <a href="Indian%20Coast%20Guard">Coast Guard of India</a> since 2011. In February 2020, President <a href="Joko%20Widodo">Joko Widodo</a> announced that he intended to have <a href="Indonesian%20Maritime%20Security%20Agency">Maritime Security Agency</a> as Indonesian <a href="coast%20guard">coast guard</a>. However, as of 2021, new maritime security law to fix overlapping authority in maritime law enforcement is still being drafted.
